Engineer colleagues! We have a great job opportunity in the Planning Department!

City of Overland Park

7,128 followers

2mo • 

Private development. Public impact.

We’re hiring a Supervisory Civil Engineer to lead a team that reviews private development plans and inspects infrastructure projects across the city.

From floodplain management to final plats, you’ll play a key role in ensuring our community grows responsibly and sustainably. This leadership role works closely with developers, residents, staff and elected officials to support safe, efficient development.

Learn more and apply now at http://bit.ly/4ffsml3.

Stuart Day 
 • 3rd+

Dean, School of Professional Studies | Vice Provost | University of Kansas | Kansas City Metro | Professor of Spanish | Managing Editor, LATR | Performance Studies | ICF / CEC Certified Higher Education Executive Coach

4mo • Edited • 

I’d like to invite you to an in-person executive coaching certification seminar at KU Edwards July 23-25. Andrew Neitlich, Center for Executive Coaching (CEC) founder and director will lead (with a little help from me). It’s a great opportunity to level up your coaching skills and earn a dual executive coaching certificate from the University of Kansas and CEC. You’ll also connect with a new network of like-mined community of professionals. Last summer’s seminar included attendees from 17 states and Canada who found the event invaluable and enjoyable!
Learn more about how the in-person Executive Coaching Certificate Seminar can take your career to new heights. https://lnkd.in/g6d7zpyh

This guy, Bill Maasen, is a big part of why Johnson County has world class parks, greenways and trails, natural resources conservation, and educational programs. It's been wonderful collaborating in many ways since meeting in Site Planning class at the KU Regents Center (now Edwards Campus) 25 years ago. Congratulations on your 39-year legacy, Bill, and enjoy your retirement!

Mark Jakubauskas 
 • 3rd+

Program Director at The University of Kansas

5mo • 

From KU Environmental Studies:

In Memoriam: Sarah Milgrim

It is with profound sadness that we share the news of the passing of Sarah Milgrim, a beloved alumna of the KU Environmental Studies program. Sarah was one of the victims of the tragic shooting at a Jewish Museum in Washington DC.
Sarah graduated with a BS in Environmental Studies from KU. She was a remarkable individual, deeply committed to fostering peace and cooperation. Her honors thesis focused on peace efforts between Israeli and Palestinian organizations, and she continued her studies at American University, including time at the University of Peace in Costa Rica.
Sarah's dedication to making the world a better place was evident in all she did. She was a wonderful person and employee, and her influence extended far beyond her time at KU. Her passion for environmental studies and peace efforts inspired many, and her loss is deeply felt by all who knew her.
We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sarah's family, friends, and all who were touched by her kindness and commitment to positive change. Her legacy will continue to inspire us.

Scott Schulte 
 • 2nd

Associate Professor of the Practice, KU Edwards Campus

6mo • 

A great Earth Day at the The University of Kansas Field Station teaching KU Environmental Studies students from Lawrence and the KU Edwards Campus about lake ecology and monitoring. Universities provide critical services through research on how the natural world works, it's health, and the impact of changes on our own health and wellbeing. I'm privileged to help Robert Hagen pass on this know-how to the next Greatest Generation.

Scott Schulte 
 • 2nd

Associate Professor of the Practice, KU Edwards Campus

7mo • 

I'm glad our professional community is uniting to support these critical water protections and  investments. Much of my career has involved water resources planning, design, and project implementation that make our  communities safer and more resilient and restore our natural resources. 

Andy Sauer 
 • 2nd

Creating Smart Stormwater Solutions at Burns & McDonnell

7mo • 

Last Wednesday, WEF and nine other national water professional organizations sent a letter to Lee Zeldin, Administrator of the EPA, regarding the impacts of reducing funding to the EPA and more importantly to state funding programs that are the backbone of water infrastructure improvements. Without clean safe drinking water, proper wastewater systems, and effective stormwater management controls we will not be a prosperous country where we can feel safe to drink the water, flush a toilet, or drive across a stream. Water is the foundation of cultures, and we are eroding our ability to just maintain what water infrastructure we have not to mention trying to make it more modern and cost effective for the next generation. Cutting funding to basic water infrastructure is not how we make America Great. 

Letter to EPA March 12 2025

2 pages

Associate Professor of the Practice

Full-time

Jul 2022 - Present · 3 yrs 4 mos

Overland Park, Kansas, United States

I am a Professor of the Practice in the Environmental Assessment Professional Science Masters and the undergraduate Environmental Studies degree completion programs where I teach undergraduate and graduate students and mentor students in capstone projects. I also conduct applied research and outreach in community and climate resilience, environmental conservation and policy.

Senior Environmental Planner

Vireo

Kansas City Metropolitan Area

Vireo is a planning and design firm where being fresh, healthy, and vigorous is more than an ideology; it's how we do business every day.

Board Member

Heartland Conservation Alliance

Jan 2012 - Present · 13 yrs 10 mos

Kansas City Metropolitan Area

Founding President of Heartland Conservation Alliance, served in this capacity until March 2016. During this period HCA grew from an all-volunteer organization to an established conservation alliance serving and collaborating with numerous federal, state, local, and not-for-profit organizations; with an annual operating budget of over $300,000, three full-time and part-time staff, and an AmeriCorps VISTA. Currently serving on the Board of Directors supporting the Conservation Work Group and Policy Work Group, the Urban Waters Federal Partnership, and ecosystem restoration at the Kansas City, Missouri Municipal Farm near the confluence of Brush Creek and the Blue River.

Lake Lenexa

Apr 2001 – Aug 2008

Show project

Lake Lenexa is a (~30 acre) man-made lake in western Lenexa KS.  The dam and spillway feature unique design elements, including a contoured ogee spillway and 360 degree accessibility via a bridge spanning the spillway stilling basin.  Black Hoof park is adjacent to the lake, and features multiple wetland areas, including an educational boardwalk.

Heartland 2050

Show project

By 2050 the population in the Omaha/Council Bluffs region is projected to nearly double. When it’s compared to regions across the country, it's in an enviable position because its quality of life is high and backed by strong neighborhoods, a solid economy, and low cost of living. Still, the region faces serious socio-economic disparities (areas of concentrated poverty and housing segregation) and challenges (projected major demographic shifts) that will test the region’s resiliency. Community leaders in the public, private, and nonprofit sectors are already taking steps through Heartland 2050, the Omaha/Council Bluff’s region’s first regional vision plan, to connect its more vulnerable communities to educational and economic opportunities. Residents want to ensure that the region continues to thrive and becomes a place where people of all walks of life have the opportunity to live, work, play and contribute. 
… more
